snippet.textDisplay: My mom has been doing this since the late 70's and I learned to make it for her when I was around 8, so it's been my go-to quick milky coffee recipe for 20 years. But now I can't make one without everybody around in my school or workplace thinking that I am the worst kind of coffee hipster. Thanks, internet.
snippet.textOriginal: My mom has been doing this since the late 70's and I learned to make it for her when I was around 8, so it's been my go-to quick milky coffee recipe for 20 years. But now I can't make one without everybody around in my school or workplace thinking that I am the worst kind of coffee hipster. Thanks, internet.

snippet.textDisplay:
Would be interesting to hear your thoughts on the canarian coffee drink "Leche Leche" (also called Café con leche y leche condensada). I usually make it like this:

1. 50-60ml (I usually go with 50ml) Condensed sweetened milk
2. A shot of double espresso 60ml
3. 130-140ml frothed milk

The traditional method is a 1/3 ratio for each ingredient but I think it's a bit to sweet at least with the water and coffee we have here.
snippet.textOriginal:
Would be interesting to hear your thoughts on the canarian coffee drink "Leche Leche" (also called Café con leche y leche condensada). I usually make it like this:

1. 50-60ml (I usually go with 50ml) Condensed sweetened milk
2. A shot of double espresso 60ml
3. 130-140ml frothed milk

The traditional method is a 1/3 ratio for each ingredient but I think it's a bit to sweet at least with the water and coffee we have here.

snippet.textDisplay: I Tried it also. Normally I use a mass produced instant coffee but I had a specialty instant coffee from a small brewery of Arabica  beans. and Used ratio 1:1:2 for coffee , sugar and hot waterbut i used spray dried coffee instead of agglomerated so it gave very thick cream of coffee. and used it in 1:5 in milk. It tasted nice. Do you have any way to make cream more soft because it didn't mix well even to last with milk.

snippet.textDisplay:
That was probably the most erudite exploration of a food fad destined to be a trivia question in the next decade.
Well played, James, well played. Cabin fever has no chance against you.
Regretfully I did not see this on the day you uploaded, but I still laughed myself silly for almost quarter of an hour when I finally did. Thank you, I needed that.


Stay safe!

snippet.textDisplay: Instant coffee is often spray-dried in a vacuum chamber, and the process creates those characteristic sharp crystals.  Instant coffee is well known to have more surfactant properties than fresh brew, and is often used for the purpose.  For example, in the Greek frappe.
snippet.textOriginal: Instant coffee is often spray-dried in a vacuum chamber, and the process creates those characteristic sharp crystals.  Instant coffee is well known to have more surfactant properties than fresh brew, and is often used for the purpose.  For example, in the Greek frappe.

snippet.textDisplay:
That foam formed because of something inside those instant coffee.
I used to whisk my ordinary instant coffee drink (with electric mini whisk), and it creates thick layer of foam on top.

But it would not form foam if we use "non-instant" ground coffee.

edit: You don't even need sugar. Just nescafe and water
snippet.textOriginal:

edit: You don't even need sugar. Just nescafe and water

snippet.textDisplay: Looks a lot like Greek frappe, only done the wrong way. We only use one sort of instant coffee for a true frappe - the original nescafe (the black one). Then we don't whisk it, but use a small kind of mixer which is terribly hard to find elsewhere than in Greece. Makes things easier. The milk part looks horrendous.
snippet.textOriginal: Looks a lot like Greek frappe, only done the wrong way. We only use one sort of instant coffee for a true frappe - the original nescafe (the black one). Then we don't whisk it, but use a small kind of mixer which is terribly hard to find elsewhere than in Greece. Makes things easier. The milk part looks horrendous.

snippet.textDisplay: So i decided to try the trending ‘Dalgona coffee’ 2 days ago. After an hour of consumption i felt irritated, nauseous, frequent urination, chest pain/heaviness, loss of appetite, insomnia and heart palpitations! These symptoms lasted the whole day and the next day. Never drinking coffee or anything caffeine related ever again.
snippet.textOriginal: So i decided to try the trending ‘Dalgona coffee’ 2 days ago. After an hour of consumption i felt irritated, nauseous, frequent urination, chest pain/heaviness, loss of appetite, insomnia and heart palpitations! snippet.textDisplay:
Here in Italy I know some places where I can find cold shaked coffe made from espresso. It's a foam made from espresso coffee and ice (you could add sugar as syrup or amaretto, but I prefer without). The machine is a milk shaker.
No sugar: only a shot of espresso and ice to make the a big cup of foam.
snippet.textOriginal:
Here in Italy I know some places where I can find cold shaked coffe made from espresso. It's a foam made from espresso coffee and ice (you could add sugar as syrup or amaretto, but I prefer without). The machine is a milk shaker.
No sugar: only a shot of espresso and ice to make the a big cup of foam.

snippet.textDisplay:
Used to do that on home in winter, but we put hot water on top instead of milk, to get an "espresso-like" crema.
We were told our parents did that when young, so think 45 years ago at least.
it was commonly done with "nescafé", it was fun but tasted awful, and yeah, needed a lot of sugar.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: you´reso funny!!! i wanted to do this because i just discovered it on insta. so i bought the ingredients, of course cheap nescafe becasue I didn´t know which one was a good quality instant coffee, i did see espresso instant coffee but it was powdery, i wasn´t sure if it was going to work. anyway i only aded 1 spoon of sugar because of "calories" and i´ve never liked my coffee too sweet. yes it was cheap nescafe quality flavor, bitter, not so sweet, did it with almond milk and ice in the bottom and was nice, ok i´d say, it´s too big of a layer, so maybe i´d put a smaller layer or whisk it less so it´s creamy but not sooo much that it doesn´t dilute with the milk after. snippet.textOriginal: you´reso funny!!! i wanted to do this because i just discovered it on insta. so i bought the ingredients, of course cheap nescafe becasue I didn´t know which one was a good quality instant coffee, i did see espresso instant coffee but it was powdery, i wasn´t sure if it was going to work. anyway i only aded 1 spoon of sugar because of "calories" and i´ve never liked my coffee too sweet. yes it was cheap nescafe quality flavor, bitter, not so sweet, did it with almond milk and ice in the bottom and was nice, ok i´d say, it´s too big of a layer, so maybe i´d put a smaller layer or whisk it less so it´s creamy but not sooo much that it doesn´t dilute with the milk after. snippet.textDisplay: I used 2 spoons of my favorite instant coffee. Really cheap but it is gentle not bitter. 2 spoons Brown soft sugar. It`s sugar with added raw sugar syrup. And  2 spoons of cold water. i used a silicon hand whisk and a plastic bowl much bigger than the one you have here. the more room for movement the faster it goes. the mix grew quite a bit. no problem getting a rich thick fluffy and sticky foam. enough for two or three cups. With ice, whole milk and a sprinkle of brown sugar on top.  it was a real treat. but i don`t think it was to sweet. couldn`t have more than one though. I think it could have made a great decorative topping for a cake or together with other desserts as well. The next day the foam turned into something that reminded me of marenge and a little of the water/Coffee had separated. So i just added some milk to the bowl and "washed" it out, Still delicious.
snippet.textOriginal: I used 2 spoons of my favorite instant coffee. Really cheap but it is gentle not bitter. 2 spoons Brown soft sugar. It`s sugar with added raw sugar syrup. With ice, whole milk and a sprinkle of brown sugar on top.  it was a real treat. but i don`t think it was to sweet. couldn`t have more than one though. I think it could have made a great decorative topping for a cake or together with other desserts as well. The next day the foam turned into something that reminded me of marenge and a little of the water/Coffee had separated. So i just added some milk to the bowl and "washed" it out, Still delicious.

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve made this with espresso! I pull a double shot just a bit short, take a spoonful of the first bit of espresso to come out, and mix that with about two and a half teaspoons of sugar (sorry, James, I’m not a very exact human most of the time). I whip that with my handheld electric milk frother until it’s light and creamy, then add the rest of my espresso to the mix and whip it up until it’s as fluffy and creamy as I can get it. It looks very similar to what you had in the video, however there is just a little bit of coffee at the very bottom of the cup that stays liquid no matter what. Less than a tablespoon, though. I’m definitely a fan!
snippet.textOriginal: I’ve made this with espresso! I pull a double shot just a bit short, take a spoonful of the first bit of espresso to come out, and mix that with about two and a half teaspoons of sugar (sorry, James, I’m not a very exact human most of the time). I whip that with my handheld electric milk frother until it’s light and creamy, then add the rest of my espresso to the mix and whip it up until it’s as fluffy and creamy as I can get it. It looks very similar to what you had in the video, however there is just a little bit of coffee at the very bottom of the cup that stays liquid no matter what. Less than a tablespoon, though. I’m definitely a fan!

snippet.textDisplay:
Several thoughts:

First, this reminds my of a shakerato - espresso and simple syrup, shaken with ice to make a foam, then strained. The foam is less stable than this.

If your wanted to use espresso, and didn't mind reduced strength, you could use a foaming agent like versawhip. You could reduce the sugar as well. This might be a good option for not overdoing things.

Finally, getting into the gadgetry: it would be quite interesting to attempt concentration via freeze or nanofiltration methods.
snippet.textOriginal:
Several thoughts:

First, this reminds my of a shakerato - espresso and simple syrup, shaken with ice to make a foam, then strained. The foam is less stable than this.

If your wanted to use espresso, and didn't mind reduced strength, you could use a foaming agent like versawhip. You could reduce the sugar as well. This might be a good option for not overdoing things.

Finally, getting into the gadgetry: it would be quite interesting to attempt concentration via freeze or nanofiltration methods.

snippet.textDisplay: Looks good.  This seems really similar to how I make Cuban coffee. You start off with sugar and then add to it the first bit of coffee brewed in a  Moka Pot and then stir vigorously to create the espuma.  It has a very similar texture to the dalgona coffee.
snippet.textOriginal: Looks good.  This seems really similar to how I make Cuban coffee. You start off with sugar and then add to it the first bit of coffee brewed in a  Moka Pot and then stir vigorously to create the espuma.  It has a very similar texture to the dalgona coffee.

snippet.textDisplay: I tried the original recipe because I only had old instant coffee lying around my gf used to drink. I thought: "How disgusting could it be? James is probably just a big wussy that got his godlike tasty bits on his tongue overwhelmeed". Well. after stirring for 3 minutes straight I had a nice thick foam. I couldn't resist to taste it. And I immediately spitted it out. And wanted to chop of my tongue. It's that disgusting. The foam itself is undrinkable. I removed 2/3s of the foamy mass and mixed it well with the milk and ice and.. it tasted like a regular instant iced coffee. Exactly like you said. Note to self: Listen to James. James is a good dude. James tries to save your tasty bits on your own tongue by sacrificing his. Thanks, James!

snippet.textDisplay: When making Hard Cider, people tend to freeze and thaw apple juice to create a concentrate for sweetening, because the sugary juice components thaw before the clear ice, without negatively affecting flavour like with boiling. Same principle as sucking on ice pops, leaving just clear ice without all the flavours. I wonder whether this would also work with coffee.
snippet.textOriginal: When making Hard Cider, people tend to freeze and thaw apple juice to create a concentrate for sweetening, because the sugary juice components thaw before the clear ice, without negatively affecting flavour like with boiling. Same principle as sucking on ice pops, leaving just clear ice without all the flavours. I wonder whether this would also work with coffee.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have tried to make it using Indonesian coffee ground "Kapal Api" with using flat dripper with 1:4 coffee:water ratio.
Add sugar for sweetening and thicken the liquid.
Using milk frother to mix it and froth it and voila it can make a good creamy foamy coffee.


IMO almost all coffee can be use to make it as long as the water is not too much

snippet.textDisplay: James, your explanation is right but I think there might be something else aiding the formation of the foam. I'm not 100% sure but I guess the instant coffe has got some surfactants. I believe they add some to make the powder more soluble and probably it helps during the drying also. Hence, It might be intresting to use one of this surfactants (soy lecitin, to give an example) to make a foam with a good espresso, don't you think?

snippet.textDisplay:
You have to mix it before drinking 🤣 I've expected that you not gonna like it, it's instant coffee 🙊

Btw, regarding using espresso, or rather not really espresso but using real coffee beans, if you look around (even in YouTube) Cuban coffee has long been using this method using the little bit of the first early pour of coffee coming out from moka pot, to be whisked with....wait for it... sugar 🤣 but the Cuban coffee version generally is not poured into milk, just with the rest of the coffee from the moka pot.

This only got viral and be called "Dalgona" because now Korea and its style & trends are the 'in' thing to millennials around the world, so it got popular easily when they see Korean youtubers and entertainers showed it... I guess 😅 I'm not k-pop enthusiasts so I have known this method from watching cuban coffee youtube videos, at first I was bewildered why do people calling it Dalgona? 🤷🏾‍♀️
snippet.textOriginal:
You have to mix it before drinking 🤣 I've expected that you not gonna like it, it's instant coffee 🙊

Btw, regarding using espresso, or rather not really espresso but using real coffee beans, if you look around (even in YouTube) Cuban coffee has long been using this method using the little bit of the first early pour of coffee coming out from moka pot, to be whisked with....wait for it... sugar 🤣 but the Cuban coffee version generally is not poured into milk, just with the rest of the coffee from the moka pot.

This only got viral and be called "Dalgona" because now Korea and its style & trends are the 'in' thing to millennials around the world, so it got popular easily when they see Korean youtubers and entertainers showed it... I guess 😅 I'm not k-pop enthusiasts so I have known this method from watching cuban coffee youtube videos, at first I was bewildered why do people calling it Dalgona? 🤷🏾‍♀️

snippet.textDisplay: "...coz, Maths all the way" is a bit of a problem in this context, because you calculated weight ratios off the volumetric ratios, so you're effectively using a recipe based on volume albeit with an added step of conversion in between. Maybe I've missed something obvious?
snippet.textOriginal: "...coz, Maths all the way" is a bit of a problem in this context, because you calculated weight ratios off the volumetric ratios, so you're effectively using a recipe based on volume albeit with an added step of conversion in between. Maybe I've missed something obvious?

snippet.textDisplay:
Meanwhile in Greece we have been drinking this kind of coffee for the last 4-5 decades. It is basically an upside down dalgona, but diluted with water (instead of milk). Of course you can add a bit of milk if you are up to it. It is called frappe and it is great for summertime (or all around the year). Since the 2000's, though, people here have been obsessed with a different kind of coffee (much better in taste of course, because f the espresso used) freddo espresso and freddo cappuccino which are basically cold espresso beaten to make it foamy-frothy with a hand mixer, ice cubes, cold water and cold frothy milk in the case of the cappuccino.
I am pretty sure James would like it better than instant coffee.
snippet.textOriginal:
Meanwhile in Greece we have been drinking this kind of coffee for the last 4-5 decades. It is basically an upside down dalgona, but diluted with water (instead of milk). Of course you can add a bit of milk if you are up to it. It is called frappe and it is great for summertime (or all around the year). Since the 2000's, though, people here have been obsessed with a different kind of coffee (much better in taste of course, because f the espresso used) freddo espresso and freddo cappuccino which are basically cold espresso beaten to make it foamy-frothy with a hand mixer, ice cubes, cold water and cold frothy milk in the case of the cappuccino. 
I am pretty sure James would like it better than instant coffee.

snippet.textDisplay: Now I tried. Used my 6 cup moka pot. As soon as the first cup of extremely dense coffee has brewed I poured it into a bowl. It weighed 36 grams. I added 2 tablespoons of sugar (also 36 grams). I whipped it using an electric hand mixer at full speed for couple of minutes (the type with two opposite rotating whiskers. The result was fine.

snippet.textDisplay: this is one of the few times, I am going to say Greeks have been doing this for ages with frappe, mixing instant coffee with water (and sugar) and the froth is so thick it never dissolved in the rest of the coffee, the glass was stained with a sticky residue. I always hated instant coffee... but at some point I thought of using it as an icing for cakes but instant coffee always put me off... oh well 7 grams of coffee 20g sugar 20g water, why not come up with something with real coffee? perhaps with the use of gelatine and cold brew, I have seen videos of people using milk with gelatine creating low fat (whipped) cream :( I don't see the point of this froth lol. it left me so unimpressed...
snippet.textOriginal: this is one of the few times, I am going to say Greeks have been doing this for ages with frappe, mixing instant coffee with water (and sugar) and the froth is so thick it never dissolved in the rest of the coffee, the glass was stained with a sticky residue. I always hated instant coffee... but at some point I thought of using it as an icing for cakes but instant coffee always put me off... oh well 7 grams of coffee 20g sugar 20g water, why not come up with something with real coffee? perhaps with the use of gelatine and cold brew, I have seen videos of people using milk with gelatine creating low fat (whipped) cream :( I don't see the point of this froth lol. it left me so unimpressed...

snippet.textDisplay: So my espresso science isn’t 100% up to speed, I do however have a deeper question regarding your comments about it not being concentrated enough. My interpretation of extraction is in the 1:2 ratio region with a ballpark of 30-35g of liquid extracted proportional to weight of dry coffee, if that is the case why is a ristretto type extraction unsuitable? Extract around 1:1, adjusting grind such flavour balance is somewhat maintained, is there a significant change in solubles in the ristretto that means it won’t foam? I acknowledge that mineral content in water can only extract a limited amount of solubles in a given volume of water, but could we not select an appropriate roast and origin to produce such an extraction?
snippet.textOriginal: So my espresso science isn’t 100% up to speed, I do however have a deeper question regarding your comments about it not being concentrated enough. My interpretation of extraction is in the 1:2 ratio region with a ballpark of 30-35g of liquid extracted proportional to weight of dry coffee, if that is the case why is a ristretto type extraction unsuitable? Extract around 1:1, adjusting grind such flavour balance is somewhat maintained, is there a significant change in solubles in the ristretto that means it won’t foam? I acknowledge that mineral content in water can only extract a limited amount of solubles in a given volume of water, but could we not select an appropriate roast and origin to produce such an extraction?
